natural problem: The same eight people sit in a certain church pew every week, but not always in the same order. Every week, each person hugs the people immediately to his or her left and right. How many weeks does it take (at a minimum) for every pair of people to hug at least once?
natural solution: There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.

However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.

So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\
&\\ \text{Week 2:} & \text{B D F H A C E G} \\ &\\ \text{Week 3:} & \text{C H E B G D A F} \\ &\\ \text{Week 4:} & \text{D H B F C G A E} \end{array}$$

a_0.formal problem:
This problem is more of a combinatorics problem than a mathematical theorem, and it doesn't translate directly into a proof in a theorem prover like Isabelle. However, one could theoretically set up a graph structure with edges representing "hugs" and formulate the problem in this way. Here is a very rough translation:

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8

type_synonym Week = "(Person * Person) set"

definition hugs :: "Week \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"hugs w \<equiv> (\<forall>p1 p2. (p1, p2) \<in> w \<or> (p2, p1) \<in> w)"

theorem
fixes weeks :: "Week list"
assumes h0 : "length weeks = 4"
and h1 : "set weeks = {({P1,P2}, {P2,P3}, {P3,P4}, {P4,P5}, {P5,P6}, {P6,P7}, {P7,P8}, {P8,P1})}"
and h2 : "\<forall>w \<in> set weeks. hugs w"
shows  "hugs (Union (set weeks))"

 ### Proof
 There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.
 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.
 So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\
 &\\ \text{Week 2:} & \text{B D F H A C E G} \\ &\\ \text{Week 3:} & \text{C H E B G D A F} \\ &\\ \text{Week 4:} & \text{D H B F C G A E} \end{array}$$

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8

type_synonym Week = "(Person * Person) set"

definition hugs :: "Week \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"hugs w \<equiv> (\<forall>p1 p2. (p1, p2) \<in> w \<or> (p2, p1) \<in> w)"

theorem
fixes weeks :: "Week list"
assumes h0 : "length weeks = 4"
and h1 : "set weeks = {({P1,P2}, {P2,P3}, {P3,P4}, {P4,P5}, {P5,P6}, {P6,P7}, {P7,P8}, {P8,P1})}"

a_0.informal problem: Eight people, labeled P1 through P8, hug each other once a week for four weeks. A hug is mutual, so if P1 hugs P2, that's the same as P2 hugging P1. Each week, the set of people who hug each other is ({P1,P2}, {P2,P3}, {P3,P4}, {P4,P5}, {P5,P6}, {P6,P7}, {P7,P8}, {P8,P1}). Prove that by the end of the four weeks, each person has hugged every other person.

a_2.formal problem:
This is a combinatorial problem, which is not directly expressible in Isabelle. But we can describe the situation in a formal way:

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8

definition "hugs = {(P1, P2), (P2, P3), (P3, P4), (P4, P5), (P5, P6), (P6, P7), (P7, P8),
(P2, P1), (P3, P2), (P4, P3), (P5, P4), (P6, P5), (P7, P6), (P8, P7)}"

definition "seatingArrangement = {(x, y). x hugs y}"

theorem
assumes h0 : "finite seatingArrangement"
shows  "card seatingArrangement = 28"
and "seatingArrangement = hugs"
and "card (hugs ∩ seatingArrangement) = 28"
and "card (hugs ∪ seatingArrangement) = 28"
and "∀ week. card {hug ∈ hugs. ∃ day. day ∈ week ∧ hug ∈ day} ≥ 28 ⟶ week ≥ 4"

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8

a_2.informal problem:
There are eight people labelled from P1 to P8. Each person hugs the next one in line, both forward and backward (for example, P1 hugs P2 and P2 hugs P1). 

A seating arrangement is defined as any situation where one person hugs another. 

Considering all possible seating arrangements, prove the following: 

1. There are exactly 28 unique hugging pairs.
2. All possible hugging pairs are present in the seating arrangement.
3. The intersection of the set of all hugging pairs and the seating arrangement also contains 28 pairs.
4. The union of the set of all hugging pairs and the seating arrangement also contains 28 pairs.
5. In any given week, if there are at least 28 unique hugging pairs, then the week must have at least 4 days.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes persons :: nat and weeks :: nat and hugs :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "persons = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> p1 p2. p1 ≠ p2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> w. w < weeks \<and> hugs p1 w = p2 \<or> hugs p2 w = p1)"
shows  "weeks = 4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The same eight people sit in a certain church pew every week, but not always in the same order. Every week, each person hugs the people immediately to his or her left and right. How many weeks does it take (at a minimum) for every pair of people to hug at least once? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.
 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.
 So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\
 &\\ \text{Week 2:} & \text{B D F H A C E G} \\ &\\ \text{Week 3:} & \text{C H E B G D A F} \\ &\\ \text{Week 4:} & \text{D H B F C G A E} \end{array}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes persons :: nat and weeks :: nat and hugs :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "persons = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall> p1 p2. p1 ≠ p2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> w. w < weeks \<and> hugs p1 w = p2 \<or> hugs p2 w = p1)"
shows  "weeks = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 8 people in a group. Each person must hug each other person exactly once. Each person can only hug one other person per week. How many weeks will it take for everyone in the group to hug each other exactly once? The final answer is 4 weeks.

a_4.formal problem:

However, Isabelle/HOL, as a theorem prover, does not naturally lend itself to these types of problems. This would likely involve using lists to represent the seating arrangements, and sets to keep track of the pairs that have been formed. 

This is not a typical use case for Isabelle/HOL, and such a problem would be more naturally solved using a programming language designed for computation, rather than a theorem prover designed for proving properties of mathematical structures.

a_5.formal problem:
The given problem is a combinatorics problem, which involves counting and arrangements. It is not straightforward to directly translate this into Isabelle, which is a theorem proving tool and doesn't directly handle these kinds of problems. However, we can make a simplified attempt to model this situation:

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8
fun next :: "Person \<Rightarrow> Person" and prev :: "Person \<Rightarrow> Person" where
"next P1 = P2" | "next P2 = P3" | "next P3 = P4" | "next P4 = P5" | "next P5 = P6" | "next P6 = P7" | "next P7 = P8" | "next P8 = P1" |
"prev P1 = P8" | "prev P2 = P1" | "prev P3 = P2" | "prev P4 = P3" | "prev P5 = P4" | "prev P6 = P5" | "prev P7 = P6" | "prev P8 = P7"

definition hugs :: "Person \<Rightarrow> Person \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"hugs p1 p2 n \<equiv> (next^^n) p1 = p2 \<or> (prev^^n) p1 = p2"

theorem
fixes n :: nat
shows  "\<forall>p1 p2. p1 \<noteq> p2 \<longrightarrow> hugs p1 p2 n \<Longrightarrow> n \<ge> 4"

This is a simplified version and doesn't fully capture the original problem (like the changing order of people each week). It assumes a fixed order of people and uses the 'next' and 'prev' functions to represent the people to the left and right. The 'hugs' function represents whether a person has hugged another person after a given number of weeks (represented by the power of 'next' or 'prev'). The theorem then states that for all pairs of different people, if they have hugged after 'n' weeks, then 'n' must be at least 4.

a_5.informal problem: Eight people are standing in a circle. Every week each person hugs the person to their immediate left and right. If, after a certain number of weeks, all the people have hugged each other, what is the minimum number of weeks that must have passed? The final answer is 4 weeks.

a_6.formal problem:
This is a complex problem that involves elements of combinatorics and graph theory, which Isabelle may not be able to handle directly. However, a simplified formulation could be as follows:

consts 
  People :: "'a set"
  Hug :: "('a * 'a) set"
  weeks :: "nat"

axiomatization
where
  People_def: "card People = 8"
and
  Hug_def: "\<forall> w. card {x. \<exists> p1 p2. p1 \<noteq> p2 \<and> (p1, p2) \<in> Hug \<and> (p2, p1) \<in> Hug} = 2 * 7 * w"
and
  Min_weeks_def: "\<forall> p1 p2. p1 \<noteq> p2 \<longrightarrow> \<exists> w \<le> weeks. (p1, p2) \<in> Hug \<and> (p2, p1) \<in> Hug"

theorem 
shows  "weeks = 4"

 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.

consts

and
  Hug_def: "\<forall> w. card {x. \<exists> p1 p2. p1 \<noteq> p2 \<and> (p1, p2) \<in> Hug \<and> (p2, p1) \<in> Hug} = 2 * 7 * w"

Every week, each person hugs exactly two other people in the group, and it is required that for each pair of people, they must hug each other at least once. What is the minimum number of weeks required for everyone in the group to have hugged everyone else at least once? The final answer is 4 weeks.

a_7.formal problem:
This problem is more of a combinatorics problem rather than a mathematical theorem to be proved. It does not translate well to Isabelle, as Isabelle is a theorem prover, not a problem solver. However, a (very) rough translation could be:

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8
type_synonym Seating = "Person list"

fun neighbors :: "Seating \<Rightarrow> (Person * Person) set" where
"neighbors [] = {}" |
"neighbors [x] = {}" |
"neighbors (x#y#xs) = {(x, y), (y, x)} \<union> neighbors (y#xs)"

definition all_pairs :: "(Person * Person) set" where
"all_pairs = {(x, y) |x y. x \<noteq> y}"

theorem
fixes seatings :: "Seating list"
assumes h0 : "length seatings = 4"
and h1 : "distinct (concat seatings)"
and h2 : "\<Union>(set (map neighbors seatings)) = all_pairs"
shows  "every pair of people to hug at least once in 4 weeks"

Note that this Isabelle code will not compile, because it is not possible to exhaustively list all possible seatings of people in a church pew in Isabelle. Also, the theorem statement is not well-defined in Isabelle. This just gives a flavor of how one might attempt to represent this problem in Isabelle, but it is not a complete translation.

 ### Proof
 There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.
 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.
 So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\

datatype Person = P1 | P2 | P3 | P4 | P5 | P6 | P7 | P8
type_synonym Seating = "Person list"

fun neighbors :: "Seating \<Rightarrow> (Person * Person) set" where
"neighbors [] = {}" |
"neighbors [x] = {}" |
"neighbors (x#y#xs) = {(x, y), (y, x)} \<union> neighbors (y#xs)"

fixes seatings :: "Seating list"
assumes h0 : "length seatings = 4"
and h1 : "distinct (concat seatings)"
and h2 : "\<Union>(set (map neighbors seatings)) = all_pairs"
shows  "every pair of people to hug at least once in 4 weeks"

Note that this Isabelle code will not compile, because it is not possible to exhaustively list all possible seatings of people in a church pew in Isabelle. Also, the theorem statement is not well-defined in Isabelle. This just gives a flavor of how one might attempt to represent this problem in Isabelle, but it is not a complete translation.
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Eight people are sitting in a church pew. They change their seating arrangement every week. After four weeks, every pair of people have sat next to each other at least once. Translate this scenario into a theorem. 

Please note that the Isabelle version isn't a perfect representation of the problem. It attempts to create a list of all possible seating arrangements, which isn't feasible in Isabelle. Also, the formulation of the theorem isn't well-defined.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "let hug_pairs_per_week = n - 1 in \<forall> pair_count. pair_count = hug_pairs_per_week * week_count \<longrightarrow> pair_count \<ge> n choose 2"
shows  "week_count \<ge> 4"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The same eight people sit in a certain church pew every week, but not always in the same order. Every week, each person hugs the people immediately to his or her left and right. How many weeks does it take (at a minimum) for every pair of people to hug at least once? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.
 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.
 So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\
 &\\ \text{Week 2:} & \text{B D F H A C E G} \\ &\\ \text{Week 3:} & \text{C H E B G D A F} \\ &\\ \text{Week 4:} & \text{D H B F C G A E} \end{array}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "let hug_pairs_per_week = n - 1 in \<forall> pair_count. pair_count = hug_pairs_per_week * week_count \<longrightarrow> pair_count \<ge> n choose 2"
shows  "week_count \<ge> 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If there are 8 people in a group and each person hugs everyone else once a week, how many weeks will it take until the total number of hugs is at least as many as the number of ways to choose 2 people out of 8? The final answer is 4 or more weeks.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> g n = 2 * n - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> g n mod 8 = 0"
shows  "g 8 = 4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The same eight people sit in a certain church pew every week, but not always in the same order. Every week, each person hugs the people immediately to his or her left and right. How many weeks does it take (at a minimum) for every pair of people to hug at least once? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 There are $8$ people, each of whom has $7$ others to hug, making $8\cdot 7$ pairs.
 However, this counts each pair twice (once for each ordering of the two people). Since order doesn't matter, the actual number of hugs that must take place is $(8\cdot 7)/2,$ which is $28.$ Every week, $7$ different hugs take place, since there are $7$ positions where two people are side-by-side.
 So, we know it will take at least $28/7 = \boxed{4}$ weeks for every pair to hug at least once. Here's one possible way they can sit so that every pair is side-by-side once: $$\begin{array}{r l} \text{Week 1:} & \text{A B C D E F G H} \\
 &\\ \text{Week 2:} & \text{B D F H A C E G} \\ &\\ \text{Week 3:} & \text{C H E B G D A F} \\ &\\ \text{Week 4:} & \text{D H B F C G A E} \end{array}$$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> g n = 2 * n - 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> g n mod 8 = 0"
shows  "g 8 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the value of $g(8)$ for a function $g(n)$ defined as $2n - 1$, for all natural numbers $n > 0$, such that $g(n)$ is divisible by 8. The final answer is 4.
